name: NPR
text:
Amid a rapid timeline, health officials across the country are pouring over CDC documents to determine how to distribute a COVID-19 vaccine.
https://t.co/g06rfFAaim

name: NPR
text:
"They didn't have no dignity in what they was doing to my brother," said Joe Prude, whose brother, Daniel, died of asphyxiation after police restrained him during a March arrest.

"They treated my brother like he was an animal in the street. A stray."
https://t.co/WgRAp529lQ

name: NPR
text: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers talks about the violence in Kenosha and how he hopes to address it, given that he lacks the support of the Republican-held state legislature. https://t.co/yLY9gt9XhV

name: NPR
text:
A new documentary traces Pepe the Frog through a variety of transformations — a stoner icon, a symbol of bigotry, a beacon of democracy — and follows the frog's creator as he fights to regain control over his character.
https://t.co/E2TvVAlSX9

name: NPR
text:
The global coronavirus death toll could total 2.8 million by the end of the year, according to projections from a prominent forecasting team.

But some disease specialists are highly skeptical of that forecast, citing concerns with the methodology.
https://t.co/a4RnJTZYod

name: NPR
text:
The split inside the Democratic Party on issues of climate and health care, and tension about whether Congress should work on more incremental reforms rather than more ambitious proposals, played out throughout the primaries.
https://t.co/oPeOzjRz98

name: NPR
text:
In writer/director Charlie Kaufman's latest, a couple spouts pat, pseudo-intellectual bromides. 

But stay with it — because that's a clue to what's really going on in this tense, surprising film.
https://t.co/WkGKioWni1

name: NPR
text:
Author Aiden Thomas' new novel follows a queer, trans Latinx teenager as he fights to prove himself to his conservative family.

He hopes the book "might help teach some folks so the trans kids in their lives don't have to."
https://t.co/PjMYTq3eUl

name: NPR
text:
Actress, producer and screenwriter @lenawaithe shares her favorite Tiny Desk concerts. 

Here’s what made her top 5: 
https://t.co/yu5jGX8U4e

name: NPR
text:
"I didn't call them to come help my brother die," Daniel Prude's brother, Joe, told NPR. "I called them to come help me get my brother some help."
https://t.co/w6Ol1UtXuN

name: NPR
text:
"Our women understood that they are leaders as well," says Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, the challenger to Belarus' president.

"They don't have to stay in their kitchens and can go and fight for their rights beside their men — and even in front of their men."
https://t.co/yNxwwYtOr8

name: NPR
text:
American teachers who work for an English tutoring service owned by ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, say they feel their jobs are in jeopardy because of Trump's crackdown on the app.

"We're collateral damage."
https://t.co/JqtsMqIuUF

name: NPR
text:
As of Aug. 28, federal prosecutors in Oregon had charges against 74 people in connection with Portland's unrest.

Of the cases charged:
• 11 are for citations 
• 42 are for misdemeanors

That means over 70% of the total charged cases aren't felonies. https://t.co/TmwvuVWPjn

name: NPR
text: As for Attorney General Barr's claim that "every police chief in every city" has identified antifa as "the ramrod for the violence" — none of the court documents from Portland's federal cases reference antifa or any broader antifascist movement.  https://t.co/6JYASMhyen

name: NPR
text: As for Attorney General Barr's assertion that "every police chief in every city" has identified antifa as "the ramrod for the violence" — none of the court documents from Portland's federal cases reference antifa or any broader antifascist movement. https://t.co/6JYASMhyen

name: NPR
text:
“Empathy, at a deep level, is the understanding that someone else's world is just as real as yours." 

Psychologist @zakijam explains how to cultivate one of our most precious human abilities on @hiddenbrain. https://t.co/2PIt6u7Enf
